title: R42562
content: The Moving to Work (MTW) program was established by Congress in 1996 to allow HUD and PHAs to test new housing assistance policies. Over 30 PHAs are currently participating in MTW, managing billions in funding. The future of MTW is uncertain, with calls for changes to the program emerging. Critics argue that MTW agencies have too much flexibility without clear outcomes. The future of the MTW program is uncertain as the current HUD-PHA agreements are set to expire in 2018. Critics argue that the program's flexibility has had negative impacts on low-income families, while supporters believe it has allowed PHAs to serve more families in unique and cost-effective ways. Conflicting views on the program's success have led to calls to end, change, or expand it. Evaluating the program's effectiveness is challenging due to its design and implementation. The MTW demonstration program's future is uncertain as current agreements are set to expire in 2018. Critics argue its flexibility has negative impacts, while supporters believe it allows PHAs to serve more families effectively. The program was meant for testing innovations in assisted housing provision, with debates on restructuring it or keeping it as is. Despite controversy, policies from MTW agencies have influenced reforms in mainstream housing programs, providing lessons for future federal housing assistance reforms. The Moving to Work Demonstration Program (MTW) allows PHAs to test innovative approaches for providing housing assistance to low-income families. Congress authorized the program in 1996 to reduce costs and increase cost-effectiveness in assisted housing. Lessons from MTW agencies have influenced reforms in mainstream housing programs, providing insights for future federal housing assistance reforms. The Moving to Work Demonstration Program (MTW) allows PHAs to test innovative approaches for providing housing assistance to low-income families. The program aims to reduce costs, increase cost-effectiveness, encourage self-sufficiency, and expand housing choices for low-income families. MTW agencies have flexibility to develop their own policies to achieve these objectives, including combining funding streams and waiving statutory requirements. The law allows PHAs to combine funding streams for housing assistance, design a "reasonable" rent policy to promote employment and self-sufficiency, and be held harmless in terms of funding. However, MTW agencies have limits on flexibility, including serving a specific number of low-income families and meeting housing quality standards. HUD is prohibited from waiving certain provisions of the U.S. Housing Act, such as public housing demolition and labor standards. PHAs must also seek public input. The law prohibits HUD from waiving certain provisions of the U.S. Housing Act, including public housing demolition and labor standards. PHAs must seek public input in developing their MTW policies, hold a public hearing, and incorporate public comments in their MTW application plan. The plan must detail how the PHA will use its flexibilities under the MTW program, which needs approval from HUD. MTW agencies must submit annual reports to HUD on fund usage and activities. The MTW demonstration program allows agencies to implement various policies and activities. The MTW demonstration program allows agencies to implement a diverse set of policies and activities in public housing. The program was developed in response to concerns about rising costs and management issues in public housing during the 1980s and 1990s. Federal policymakers considered strategies to reduce costs and improve management, leading to the development of the MTW program. The concept of "block granting" was explored as a way to devolve assisted housing programs to the local level. The MTW demonstration program was developed to explore block granting and devolving assisted housing programs to the local level. It aimed to increase family self-sufficiency, reduce housing costs through market-based approaches, and maintain federal regulation for achieving housing goals like desegregation. The MTW demonstration program, aimed at reducing assisted housing costs through market-based approaches, was announced by HUD in December 1996. 30 PHAs were selected to participate, with agreements signed in 1998 or 1999. Six agencies opted out, possibly due to delays or increased flexibility provided by a housing reform law in 1998. Due to a housing reform law in 1998, six MTW agencies chose not to participate in the program. HUD allocated the remaining spots to housing authorities with over 2,500 units. Congress directed HUD to add more PHAs to the MTW program through various acts, with competitive slots available to high-performing PHAs with fewer than 5,000 units. HUD recently selected four agencies to participate in the MTW program, despite criticisms of their implementation. Some PHAs were chosen despite prior poor performance, leading to a lack of uniformity in program structure and difficulties in data collection. HUD's data systems were unable to accommodate variations in PHA income and rent policies, hindering data collection from MTW PHAs. This resulted in a lack of information on tenant characteristics, making it challenging to evaluate the effects of MTW policies on tenant outcomes and program costs. HUD has faced criticism for insufficient monitoring of the program's implementation, leading to recommendations for improved oversight. In response, a standard MTW agreement with uniform language was introduced in 2008. HUD issued a report recommending improved monitoring and oversight of the MTW program. In response, a standard MTW agreement with uniform language was implemented in 2008, extending participation until 2018. However, the agreement does not standardize performance data, limiting HUD's evaluation of MTW agencies' policies. MTW agencies have adopted a wide range of program activities, with some fully transforming their assisted housing programs while others making more modest policy changes. They have discretion in three policy areas: merging funding streams, determining assistance levels and conditions, and other administrative flexibilities. MTW agencies like the Chicago Housing Authority and Atlanta Housing Authority have used their funding flexibility to redevelop public housing stocks, attracting private investment for new mixed-income communities. The fixed 10-year merged MTW funding stream played a crucial role in obtaining financing for these transformation plans. The merged MTW funding stream allowed agencies like the Chicago Housing Authority and Atlanta Housing Authority to obtain financing for transforming public housing with private investment. Other MTW agencies, such as Keene Housing Authority and Housing Authorities of Santa Clara and San Jose, used funding flexibility to convert public housing to project-based voucher developments, aiming to leverage additional outside financing. In the traditional Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher program, PHAs can "project-base" vouchers by reserving units for low-income tenants in private buildings. MTW agencies have experimented with alternative rent structures, including maximum and minimum rents, flat rents, delayed rent increases, stepped rents, and alternative subsidies. Most agencies have their own minimum rent policies, some have tiered rent policies, and others have flat rent policies. Additionally, some agencies have simplified the utility calculation for determining tenant subsidies.
